newsitem.title: INDIA: CRICKET-IN-FORM S.AFRICA FACE BIG TEST OF NERVE.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-IN-FORM S.AFRICA FACE BIG TEST OF NERVE.

text.p: South Africa, winners of all six preliminary matches in their run-up to the final of the Titan Cup triangular one-day series, face their toughest challenge from hosts India on Wednesday.

The South Africans, playing with clinical efficiency, have already beaten India comprehensively three times in the tournament. The Australians were eliminated after failing to win a single match in the series.
But the final day-night match in front of an anticipated 40,000 vociferous home supporters at Bombay's Wankhede stadium may put the visitors under immense pressure.
India, their confidence boosted by the sensational five-run, last-over victory against Australia on Sunday at Mohali, are expected to turn on their best showing at one of their favourite venues.
"Our first job will be to keep the massive crowd quiet and then carry on as we have been doing so far," South African coach Bob Woolmer said.
Woolmer will be happy that two of his injured strike bowlers Fanie de Villiers and Brian McMillan are fit for the final.
With Lance Klusener, bowling fairly well and coming good with the bat, the South Africans face the problem of who to drop.
Poor form and injuries have forced frequent changes to the Indian side which will be without two of their leading batsmen -- Saurav Ganguly and Navjot Sidhu -- who are both injured.
Sidhu has been replaced by right-hand batsman Sanjay Manjrekar who will be skipper Sachin Tendulkar's fourth new opening partner.
Stability in the opening slot continues to be India's main worry but they can take heart from the manner in which the side's batting finally clicked at Mohali.
India rattled a formidable 289 for six to put pressure on Australia whose failure was a big disappointment in the series.
Though India's strength is their batting, they will persist with four specialist bowlers, expecting Robin Singh, recalled after a seven year absence, to serve as an all-rounder in the side.
South Africa, on the other hand, are arguably the best all-round side in one-day cricket, thanks in part to their outstanding fielding. They have won 25 of their 28 one-day matches this year.

"We have won three tournaments recently and have beaten world cup champions Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Australia and India. That should make us the best side in the game today," said South African captain Hansie Cronje.
